title: Bridging the Structure/Agency Divide: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Disadvantage and Education
abstractText:
Starting with the concerns and experiences of practitioners, this seminar series will bring academics from education and other disciplines together with practitioners and other stakeholders.  It will explore how different theoretical perspectives on the links between education and disadvantage, including both structural and agentic explanations,  can be combined to generate new understanding and to inform practice, complementing the ‘what works’ evidence that is currently being invested in and advocated by government. Cross-disciplinary social scientific tools will be developed to explain the structures and processes that shape learning moments such that ‘what works’ does work, and why ‘what works’ in one school or classroom might ‘work’ less well or differently in another, or might be capable or incapable of ‘scaling up’.

Focusing directly on practitioner concerns and experiences of working in classrooms situated in contexts characterised as ‘disadvantaged’, the seminar series will enable:

  • genuine and innovative interdisciplinary working between scholars, with all the tensions and challenges that this entails
  • a diverse community to engage with research and theory from fields outside education to provide new challenge and understanding
  • a theoretical reframing of the paralysing structure/agency debates of recent years.
